description: Microbes are a fundamental part of life on this planet. This course will explore the causes and consequences of the distribution and abundance of microbes (microbial ecology) as well as microbial evolution on human health and disease risk. We will address the interplay between human society and microbial ecology and evolution in shaping disease risk and directing scientific study. This course will apply concepts from basic biology, ecology, and evolution to study infectious microbes as living creatures.
name: HUMANS IN MICROBIAL WRLD

values.comments: Students in Professor Brisson’s course really appreciated this science class for non-science majors.  While most students had no science background and found the material challenging, they appreciated the class discussions.  Many suggested that the professor include supplemental readings as a way to help those students with little knowledge of biology.  Students felt Professor Brisson was very knowledgeable and interesting, led a good discussion, and was open to new ideas.
